questions.question: All of the following can be done to transport a polytrauma patient who is conscious except?

options.A: Strap their thorax, abdomen, and lower limbs on a stretcher
options.B: Place in prone position to prevent aspiration
options.C: Put the patient on a lateral position and shift him immediately
options.D: Roll the patient onto a hard board

questions.explanation: Placing a conscious polytrauma patient in a prone position is not recommended as it can cause respiratory distress and is not typically done to prevent aspiration in this context.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: A man met with a road traffic accident, which resulted in paralysis of both his upper and lower limbs. He has not passed urine and tenderness is elicited in the cervical region. What will you advise regarding radiography?

options.A: The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used after neck stabilization.
options.B: Instruct the radiographer to take cervical and chest X-ray.
options.C: Instruct the radiographer to take cervical X-ray AP and lateral view without any cervical support.
options.D: Order a cervical X-ray and shift the patient from the trolley by himself.

questions.explanation:
The given clinical situation suggests a cervical spine injury due to trauma. The patient should not be shifted and a portable X-ray machine should be used for radiography after neck stabilization. Management in a trauma patient with a suspected cervical fracture involves the following steps: 
   1. Spinal immobilization with a rigid cervical collar and a long spine board is the immediate step in the management of blunt/penetrating cervical trauma cases.
   2. It is followed by a gross assessment of spinal cord function by eliciting extremity movement. Tenderness over the injured vertebrae or the presence of a deformity is indicative of an associated fracture.
   3. Imaging is done by X-ray or CT. Portable X-ray machines are preferred to avoid further injury while mobilizing the patient. They are useful in visualizing thoracic and lumbar vertebrae but not the cervicothoracic junction. Cervical CT has been made the modality of choice in most emergency departments owing to the high quality of images that can be obtained.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: A 25-year-old construction worker sustained an injury to his neck after falling from the tenth floor of a construction site. The first aid team that rushed to his rescue log-rolled him. According to ATLS, what is the minimum number of people required for log-rolling this patient?
questions.explanation: The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for the safe maneuver of log-roll in patients suffering from trauma. The first person is assigned to restrict the motion of the head and neck. The second person is positioned on the same side of the patient's torso. He manually prevents segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while transferring the patient. The third person is responsible for moving the patient's legs. The fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back. Note: In a patient known to have a fracture of the extremities, a minimum of 5 people are required to safely perform the log-roll maneuver.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about acute spinal injury is false?

options.A: Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to the loss of parasympathetic tone
options.B: Immediate respiratory suppression can occur due to the involvement of the phrenic nerve
options.C: Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS help to determine the need for radiographic evaluation
options.D: Patients with neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as soon as possible

questions.explanation: Hypotension in acute spinal injury is due to the loss of sympathetic tone. The classic presentation of neurogenic shock is hypotension in the setting of warm, well-perfused extremities in a paralyzed patient. This condition requires intravascular volume expansion and vasopressor support. Option B: High cervical spinal cord injury (SCIs) may have immediate respiratory suppression. This requires airway management and ventilatory support because of paresis of the phrenic nerves. Hypoventilation can occur from paralysis of the intercostal muscles (injury to the lower cervical or upper thoracic spinal cord) or the diaphragm (injury to C3 to C5). Option C: Canadian C-Spine rule and NEXUS are validated clinical decision tools to help determine the need for radiographic evaluation and to clinically clear the cervical spine. NEXUS criteria: There are five criteria included under NEXUS. If a trauma patient meets all five criteria, then no radiography is required and the cervical c-spine collar may be removed. However, if any one of the criteria is met, then radiography is done to evaluate further. The NEXUS criteria include: No posterior midline cervical spinal tenderness, No evidence of intoxication, A normal level of alertness, No focal neurologic deficit, and No painful distracting injuries. Option D: Patients with or without neurological deficits should be removed from the backboard as soon as possible. A patient who is allowed to lie on the hardboard for more than 2 hours is at high risk for pressure ulcers.

questions.question: A 20-year-old college student sustained a superficial injury to his neck during a bar fight. What is the probable cause of sudden death in this patient?

options.B: Air embolism through the external jugular vein

questions.explanation: Air embolism through the external jugular vein is a cause of sudden death in patients with superficial neck injuries. All other structures are deeper structures, hence they are not involved much in superficial injuries of the neck.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented to the emergency department after suffering injuries in the neck during an armed robbery. On examination, several bleeding lacerated injuries are visible at the front and lateral aspects of the neck. Which of the following is not an indication for immediate surgical exploration?
questions.explanation: Fluid responsive hemorrhagic shock is not an indication for immediate surgical intervention. The following are the indications for immediate surgical exploration of neck trauma. They are also known as the hard signs of neck trauma: Pulsatile bleeding, Expanding hematoma, Air bubbling from penetrating injury, Absent radial pulse, Respiratory distress, Presence of neurological deficit, Fluid resistant hemorrhagic shock, Audible bruit or palpable thrill, Signs of stroke/ cerebral ischemia. The presence of any of these hard signs indicates major neurovascular/ airway injury and is an indication for surgical exploration of the trauma region as soon as possible. Neck trauma is classified based on the different regions of the neck. Zone I: thoracic inlet to cricoid, associated with maximum mortality. It contains large vascular structures as well as the trachea and esophagus. Zone II: cricoid cartilage to the angle of mandible, most commonly prone to injury and most easily accessible for surgery. It contains the carotid and vertebral arteries, jugular veins, and structures of the aerodigestive tract. Zone III: angle of the mandible to the base of the skull. Structures within zone III include blood vessels that are difficult to expose surgically. Management: If the patient is hemodynamically unstable: neck exploration. If the patient is stable: Zone II injury: Conservative management. Zone I and Zone III: Angiography and angioembolization are indicated. If it fails, then neck exploration should be done.

questions.question: A 38-year-old man was brought to the emergency department after suffering a stab injury to the lower chest. On presentation, he had bradycardia and hypotension which did not improve despite IV fluid administration. Chest radiography showed clear lung fields. What is the next step in management?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of a patient with a stab injury and hypotension not responding to IV fluids indicates persistent hypotension due to ongoing hemorrhage and the next step in the management is to perform an eFAST. Cardiogenic shock or hemorrhagic shock are the most likely causes of persistent hypotension in a trauma patient. Ultrasound evaluation using eFAST to look for pericardium, pleural cavities, and abdomen in combination with plain radiographs of the chest and pelvis will usually identify the source of the bleed. In patients with persistent hypotension due to blunt trauma, the pelvis should be wrapped in a sheet for stabilization until radiography can be done. Evaluation of CVP or ultrasound of the IVC may further assist in distinguishing between cardiogenic and hypovolemic shock. It is mostly fatal if not controlled, and requires immediate management. Blood and plasma transfusions are provided in a ratio of 2:1. Patients with persistent hypotension requiring surgical intervention include: • Blunt trauma and massive hemothorax • Penetrating trauma • Hemoperitoneum • Gunshot injuries to the chest or abdomen • Penetrating weapon remaining in place. Other options: Options C and D: CECT can be done only when the patient is hemodynamically stable. Option B: Tube thoracostomy has no role in this patient's management since the X-ray shows clear lung fields.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: eFAST is least helpful in diagnosing which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, eFAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma) is least useful in diagnosing retroperitoneal hematoma, as the sensitivity of ultrasound for detecting retroperitoneal hematomas is extremely poor. FAST is a rapid, noninvasive bedside test that uses sonography to detect free fluid in the abdomen and assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. Technique: The patient is placed in a supine position. With a 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer, the following regions are scanned: Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries; Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison's pouch; Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury; Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas. eFAST stands for extended FAST and incorporates left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax. Computed Tomography (CT Scan) is the investigation of choice for retroperitoneal injury, but it can only be done in a hemodynamically stable patient.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man is rushed to the emergency department following a high-speed road traffic collision. His heart rate is 124 beats/min and BP is 78/56 mmHg on the right arm, and 64/50 mmHg on the left arm. A portable chest x-ray shows a widened mediastinum but normal lung and cardiac silhouette. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of aortic injury. The investigation of choice in this hemodynamically unstable patient is transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). In hemodynamically stable patients, the investigation of choice is CECT or CT angiogram. Traumatic aortic injuries are commonly seen in deceleration injuries (e.g., road traffic accidents). The most common site of aortic injury is the isthmus, near the attachment of ligamentum arteriosum. Clinical features of aortic injuries: Hypotension, difference in blood pressure in bilateral limbs, absent pulse in the unilateral limb, widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. Management: Volume replacement: fluid therapy and blood transfusion, permissive hypotension: Beta-blockers, such as esmolol, immediate surgical repair: endovascular stenting, or open surgical repair with Dacron graft.

questions.question: A young man was rushed to the casualty with multiple rib fractures. On examination, you notice a paradoxical movement of the chest, and the patient is diagnosed with respiratory failure. How would you manage him?

options.D: Internal operative fixation of the fractured segments

questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of flail chest with respiratory failure. Management of this condition is IPPV (invasive positive pressure ventilation). A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage. This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e., 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards, and therefore, less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards. This is known as paradoxical respiration. The diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm, the paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment can be observed for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement, and the associated lung contusion are all causes of hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax. Treatment: • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided. • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. • IPPV (Intermittent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for patients developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen. Treatment algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure: Flail chest and respiratory failure Yes Major organ injury, lung contusion or inability to protect the airway Intubation and mechanical ventilation No Non-invasive mechanical ventilation Yes No Effective non-invasive mechanical ventilation Yes Chest wall instability, interfering with weaning Consider surgical fixation of the rib cage No Weaning when tolerated

questions.question: A 30-year-old man involved in a road traffic accident says that his bike handle hit the right side of his chest. On palpation, he had tenderness in the right upper chest. Chest radiograph shows a fracture in the right third rib. Which of the following should you not do while managing him?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of a rib fracture. Strapping is not done for rib fractures because it prevents the patient from taking deep breaths. This can lead to lung collapse. The vital step in the management of rib fractures is to reduce pain and prevent the development of pneumonia. Rib fracture causes intense pain during breathing and increases the risk of pulmonary infections as the patient is not able to cough forcefully. In mild to moderate cases, pain can be managed by intravenous opioids. In severe cases, patients may require epidural analgesia. In addition to adequate analgesia, chest physiotherapy like deep breathing, frequent coughing, incentive spirometry should be encouraged in these patients. This prevents the development of pneumonia and lung collapse. When chest wall injuries result in respiratory failure, mechanical ventilation should be provided.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presents to the ER with a history of RTA. On examination, GCS is 15/15, heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, and there is elevated JVP. The right chest is hyperresonant on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen was soft. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of trauma with decreased breath sounds and a hyper-resonant note on percussion indicates pneumothorax. The presence of tachycardia, hypotension, and elevated JVP is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Tension pneumothorax develops when there is a parietal or visceral pleural tear. This tear acts as a one-way valve, i.e., air enters the pleural space from the lung or chest wall during inspiration but has no way to escape during expiration, leading to the collapse of the affected lung. It is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, acute dyspnea, sudden onset hemodynamic compromise (tachycardia, hypotension, low O2 saturation, loss of consciousness), neck vein distention, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, decreased chest movements on the affected side, hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side, and absent or decreased breath sounds on the affected side. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed awaiting radiological confirmation. Management includes: Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy with a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location is at the 2nd intercostal space in the mid-clavicular line. Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th intercostal space in the triangle of safety. The triangle of safety is bounded anteriorly by the lateral border of the pectoralis major, posteriorly by latissimus dorsi, and inferiorly by a horizontal line at the level of the nipple. Other options: Option A: Pericardial tamponade can mimic tension pneumothorax, but the absence of a tympanic note on percussion rules out its possibility. A patient with pericardial tamponade can present with hypotension, raised JVP, and muffled heart sounds (Beck's triad), with normal breath sounds and no tracheal shift. Option C: Dullness in percussion at the base of the left inferior angle of scapula in conjunction with tubular breath sounds (Ewart's sign), chest pain that improves while sitting upright and worsens when lying down, and pulsus paradoxus are indicative of pericardial effusion. Pericardial effusion develops into tamponade when the effusion leads to increased pressure, impairing ventricular filling and reducing cardiac output. Option D: Massive hemothorax is the accumulation of >1500 ml of blood or one-third or more of the patient's blood volume in the chest cavity. The patient will have collapsed neck veins, decreased breath sounds, and a dull note on percussion.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: A 20-year-old patient presented to the ER with tension pneumothorax following a road traffic accident. What is the first line of management?

options.A: Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line
options.B: Insert wide bore needle in 5th ICS in the mid-clavicular line
options.C: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-axillary line
options.D: Insert wide bore needle in 2nd ICS in the mid-clavicular line

questions.explanation: Insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th intercostal space anterior to the mid-axillary line is the first-line management in adults with tension pneumothorax. Management of tension pneumothorax: Immediate management: Needle decompression or needle thoracostomy, i.e., insertion of a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line. Definitive management: Tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety. If a sucking wound is present, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides. Following this, a chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Note: According to ATLS 10th edition, in adults, needle thoracostomy or needle decompression location is changed to 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line from 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line. In the pediatric age group, the needle thoracostomy location remains at the 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line. This update was recommended since chest wall thickness influences the likelihood of success with needle decompression. Inserting a needle in 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line had better outcomes.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: An intern placed an intercostal drainage tube in a patient. Which of the following steps is incorrect?

options.A: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid-axillary line to place the tube
options.B: Inserted tube along the lower border of upper rib
options.C: Directed tube posteriorly to prevent injury

questions.explanation: An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the upper border of the lower rib at the 5th intercostal space (ICS) to prevent damage to the neurovascular bundle. Hence, option B is incorrect. Chest tube insertion (thoracostomy) is indicated in pneumothorax, hemothorax, chylothorax, and pleural effusion in order to drain air/fluid from the pleural space. The triangle of safety, usually in the 5th intercostal space, is the safest site for chest tube insertion, it is bound by: anterior to the mid-axillary line, above the horizontal line marked by the level of the nipple, and below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle. Insertion of chest drain includes penetration of skin, muscle, and pleura, blunt dissection of the parietal pleura, digital examination along the tract into the pleural space, withdrawal of central trochar and positioning of drain, gauging the distance, suture placement of insertion. Contraindications include pulmonary adhesions, pulmonary trauma, coagulopathy, and diaphragmatic hernia. Complications of this procedure include infection at the site of insertion, unintentional injury to the lung - hemothorax, intercostal nerve/vessel injury, subcutaneous hematoma/emphysema.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by

options.A: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
options.B: Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.explanation: Oscillation of the water column level (moving up and down during respiration) within the tube in the water seal chamber is indicative of a functioning (patent) ICD tube. During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known as tidaling. Other options: Option A: Continuous bubbling indicates an air leak in the drainage system, which should be corrected. Option C: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its functioning. Option D: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with a stab injury to his chest. On examination, the patient is found to be hemodynamically unstable. His neck veins are engorged and heart sounds are muffled. Which of the following statements about the patient is false?

options.A: Cardiac tamponade is likely to be present
options.B: The entry wound is sealed on all 4 sides with an occlusive dressing if pneumothorax is suspected
options.C: eFAST is done to confirm blood in the pericardial sac

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of hemodynamic instability and muffled heart sounds are suggestive of cardiac tamponade. The entry wound is sealed on only 3 sides with an occlusive dressing if a pneumothorax is suspected. When there is a pneumothorax with a sucking wound, the immediate step is to cover the wound with gauze pieces and tape on 3 sides. As the patient breathes in, the dressing occludes the wound, preventing air from entering into the thoracic cavity. During exhalation, the open end of the dressing allows air to escape from the pleural space. This is known as a flutter-valve effect. Following this, a chest tube is inserted away from the site of the wound. Cardiac tamponade must be differentiated from tension pneumothorax in a patient with hemodynamic instability and distended neck veins. Cardiac tamponade is characterized by Beck's triad: muffled heart sounds, distended neck veins, and hypotension. Tension pneumothorax is characterized by absent breath sounds and hyper-resonance on percussion on the affected side. These are not present in a patient with cardiac tamponade. Diagnosis of cardiac tamponade can be done by eFAST, which shows fluid in the pericardial sac. Definitive management is emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: In a blast injury, which of the following organs is least vulnerable to the blast wave?
questions.explanation: In a blast injury, the liver is the least vulnerable to blast wave (primary blast) injury. Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion. Primary blast injuries result from the rapid overpressure or shock waves produced by an explosion. These injuries result from the dramatic changes in barometric pressure projecting outwards from the point of detonation. They predominantly cause damage to air-filled hollow organs of the body from rapid pressure change (barotrauma). This includes the middle ear, lungs, and GI tract. The most sensitive and most frequently injured hollow organs are the tympanic membranes > lungs. Blast damage to the lungs is the most common cause of life-threatening injury following an explosion. Solid organs are the most resistant to blast injuries as the parenchymal disruption requires very high levels of overpressure. Classification of blast injuries: Primary blast due to air pressure from the blast shockwave (overpressure), Secondary blast fragments from the blast, following a detonation, Tertiary blast gross movements of persons, objects, or infrastructure by the blast wind, Miscellaneous causes penetrating/fragmentation, blunt trauma, exposure to explosive products or toxic substances, environmental contaminant, Quaternary blast the intentional addition of biological or radioactive material to the explosive device, Quinary blast. Examples: Tympanic membrane injury, blast lung, intestinal blast injury, all penetrating injuries, blunt and crush injuries, traumatic amputation, burns, inhalation injury, radiation sickness, infection.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: Following a motor vehicle collision, a 30-year-old male sustained blunt trauma to his abdomen. What is the organ most likely to be injured?
questions.explanation: The spleen is the most common organ involved in blunt trauma injury of the abdomen. In blunt trauma, organs that cannot yield to impact by elastic deformation are most likely to be injured, namely, the solid organs (liver, spleen, and kidneys). For penetrating trauma, organs with the largest surface area when viewed from the front are most prone to injury (small bowel, liver, and colon). Additionally, since bullets and knives usually follow straight lines, adjacent structures are commonly injured (e.g., the pancreas and duodenum). Deceleration injures the pedicled organs by shearing the organs from their points of attachment to the retroperitoneum (intestines and kidney). The most commonly injured bowel in cases of blunt trauma of the abdomen is the jejunum.
questions.chapter_heading: Trauma - Spinal, Thoracic and Abdominal Injuries

questions.question: A 30-year-old man stabbed his elder brother using a knife over a property dispute. Which is the most common organ that is likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.explanation: The liver is the most common organ to be injured in penetrating stab injury of the abdomen. It is due to its anterior location, size, and fragile parenchyma. The most common organ injured in blunt trauma to the abdomen is spleen > liver. The most common organ injured in gunshot injury is the small intestine > colon.

questions.question: A patient is shifted for emergency laparotomy for the management of an intra-abdominalhaemorrhage, following a road traffic accident. Intraoperatively, you find an active bleed fromthe liver. Which of the following techniques will you use to control the bleed?
questions.explanation: 169The hepatoduodenal ligament can be clamped to decrease active hemorrhage from the liver. Thisis called Pringle's maneuver.This maneuver applies pressure on the portal triad which contains bile duct, portal vein andhepatic artery. This helps distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding from hepaticvein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist with the hepatoduodenal ligament clamped. Theliver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlled with sutureligation.4 P's in the management of liver injuries are:• Push compression of the edges of the laceration•-Pringle - applying pressure on the portal triad•Plug the defects with silicon tubes• Pack - apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding.©MARROW

questions.question: A patient develops abdominal compartment syndrome following an emergency laparotomy.Which of the following is false about this condition?
questions.explanation: Central venous pressure (CVP) increases due to inferior vena cava (IVC) and portal veincompression in abdominal compartment syndrome.Abdominal Compartment Syndrome (ACS) is defined as increased intra-abdominal pressure(IAP) >20 mm Hg resulting in compression of abdominal structures (Normal IAP = 5-7 mmHgand intraabdominal hypertension IAP 12 mmHg).This produces fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise.Elevated intra-abdominal pressure leads to a decrease in venous return resulting in decreasedcardiac output. An increase in heart rate partly compensates this.Systemic vascular resistance (afterload) is increased by the compression of both the aorta andsystemic vasculature. This also leads to an increase in renal vascular resistance leading to areduced glomerular filtration rate.170Causes of primary ACS include:• Abdominal trauma⚫ Hemorrhage• Intestinal obstruction•⚫ Retroperitoneal hematomaCauses of secondary ACS include:• Pregnancy• Ascites• Ileus• Intra-abdominal sepsis•• Large-volume fluid replacement (greater than 3L)

questions.question: Which of the following statements about abdominal compartment syndrome is false?

options.B: Hypoxia due to increased peak inspiratory pressure
options.C: Hypotension due to decrease in venous return

questions.explanation: Oliguria is due to reduced renal blood flow.An increase in renal vascular resistance leads to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate andimpaired urine output.Abdominal compartment syndrome is characterized by:• A sudden increase in intraabdominal pressure• Increased peak inspiratory pressure• Hypercarbia and respiratory acidosis• Decreased urinary output - due to reduced renal blood flow•Hypotensionsecondary to decreased venous return to the heart.

questions.question: You are evaluating a patient in the burns unit, who had sustained third-degree burns to herabdomen and lower limbs (BSA of 30%). She had received 9 liters of Ringer's lactate at aprimary center. On examination, extensive abdominal eschars are seen. BP - 84/50 mmHg,HR - 118 bpm and urine output has been less than 15 ml for the past 2 hours. The ventilatorshows a peak airway pressure of 42 cm H2O. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS).Measurement of bladder pressure using a urinary bladder catheter is the next best step in themanagement of this patient.The oliguria and hypotension in isolation could be suggestive of under-resuscitation. However, thehistory of large volume fluid administration, presence of abdominal eschars along with very highpeak airway pressures should raise the suspicion for ACS.Abdominal compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of intra-abdominal pressure >20mmHg with associated organ compression and dysfunction:Compression of the IVC leads to decreased cardiac output, and consequent increase in systemicvascular resistance, leading to hypotension.171• Cephalad displacement of the diaphragm results in decreased thoracic volumes and results inelevated peak and plateau pressures.• Renal compression can lead to increased renal vascular resistance, decreased GFR and low urineoutput.Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen forintra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome.Note: Direct methods such as pressure transducers and intraperitoneal catheters are moreaccurate but are limited by their invasiveness.Grade of Intra-abdominal hyIntra-abdominal pressure (IApertension (IAH)Grade IP)12-15 mmHgGrade II16-20 mmHgGrade III21-25 mmHgGrade IV>25 mmHg

questions.question: 151A patient is admitted to the intensive care unit following a trauma to the abdomen. Hisintraabdominal pressure is found to be 24 mmHg. What is the grade of abdominalhypertension?
questions.explanation: Intraabdominal pressure (IAP) of 24 mm Hg falls under grade III of intra-abdominal hypertension(IAH).Normal intraabdominal pressure is 5 to 7 mmHg. Any acute process in the abdomen such astrauma, intestinal perforation, peritonitis, or acute pancreatitis can increase the intra-abdominalpressure. Increased abdominal pressure can diminish the blood flow to the abdominal organs anddecrease the venous return to the heart.Measurement of bladder (intravesical) pressure is the standard method to screen forintra-abdominal hypertension (IAH) and abdominal compartment syndrome.Grade III intra-abdominal hypertension is associated with hypoxia, ARDS and seriouscomplications. It is associated with abdominal compartment syndrome which is defined as asustained IAP >20 mmHg associated with organ dysfunction/failure.Grade of Intra-abdominal hypertension (IAH)Intra-abdominal pressure (IAP)Grade I12-15 mmHgGrade II16-20 mmHgGrade III21-25 mmHgGrade IV>25 mmHg

questions.question: Following a road traffic accident, a child presents with abdominal pain. On examination,vitals are stable and tenderness is present in the left lumbar region. Which is the bestinvestigation of choice for this patient?
questions.explanation: 172The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region followinga road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in ahemodynamically stable patient.Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Radiological investigationsare indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock in combination with microscopic haematuria,pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration,extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries andeffectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of thenormal renal contour.Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most of the penetrating injuries require surgicalrenal exploration.Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:• Massive hemorrhage• Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury).•Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematomaRelative indications are:•• Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction• Bowel or pancreatic injuries•Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess•Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys• Renal hypertensionExploratory laparotomy is recommended in stable patients with penetrating renal injuries.

questions.question: A trauma patient suffers a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He is managedconservatively. However, after a few days, he presents with a urinoma. The next bestmanagement for this patient would be?
questions.explanation: The patient with a history of grade IV renal injury (renal laceration with urine extravasation) whodevelops a persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should bemanaged with the placement of an internal ureteral stent.In patients not cured by ureteral stenting, percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainmay be required.Management of renal injuriesBlunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is self-limiting. Blunt trauma is mostlytreated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.Grading of injury through CECT• If hemodynamically stable• Conservative management - Bedrest & hemodynamic monitoring173•In grade IV, a repeat CT scan to ensure the extravasation of urine has resolved.• If hemodynamically unstable●Surgical exploration and repair• In grade V, nephrectomy.

questions.question: While performing emergency laparotomy for an unstable RTA case with blunt abdominaltrauma, the surgeon notices a hematoma around the left kidney. What will be the next step inthe management of this patient?
questions.explanation: The next step in the surgical management of the patient found to have a hematoma around thekidney, intraoperatively, will be a single-shot intravenous pyelography (IVP).If immediate operative exploration for other injuries is required, renal injury staging can beperformed while the patient is still in the operating room, using single-shot IVP. It is useful inassessing the function of the kidneys and the extent of the injury. If the IVP is abnormal or thehematoma is pulsatile, then renal exploration should be performed.Note: CECT is the method of choice for staging a patient with hemodynamically stable renaltrauma presenting at the emergency room.

questions.question: An 8-year-old child presents with grade 2 splenic injury following blunt trauma to theabdomen. On examination, there are no signs of bleeding. Which of the following is the mostappropriate management for this child?
questions.explanation: Conservative management is the most appropriate management in this child.Selective Non-Operative Management (SNOM) is usually followed in:• Stable patients with no active bleeding• Patients younger than 55 years of age• Patients with grade I, II, III injuries.Any patient who is hemodynamically unstable, has active bleeding, and has grade IV and Vsplenic injury should be managed by surgery.174GradeI/IIManagement of splenic injuryUsuallystableCECT(IOC)ConservativemanagementMonitor vitals,serial 24 hour CECT,measure hematocritIf grade ofinjury increasesMARROGradeIHAngioembolizationFails, unstable,contrast blushGradeIV/VUnstableSurgery(splenic preservation)SplenorrhaphyFAST(IOC)SplenectomyOMARROW

questions.question: A young male patient is taken up for laparotomy following a stab injury. Pringle's maneuveris done. Which of the following statements is false about this maneuver?

options.A: It is used to differentiate between hepatic arterial and hepatic venous bleed
options.B: Arterial bleed persists on performing the maneuver
options.C: Hepatic pedicle is compressed at the epiploic foramen
options.D: Prolonged application of pressure can lead to hepatic necrosis

questions.explanation: Pringle maneuver may be required for the treatment of liver laceration. Hepatic venousbleed persists on performing this maneuver.When there is severe bleeding from the liver, this maneuver is a viable adjunct to slow blood flowenough to visualize liver injury. The hepatoduodenal ligament is clamped at the epiploic foramenor the foramen of Winslow. This applies pressure on the portal triad that contains bile duct, portalvein and hepatic artery. This helps to distinguish hepatic arterial and portal venous bleeding fromhepatic vein bleeding. Hepatic venous bleed will persist when the hepatoduodenal ligamentclamped. The liver laceration can then be explored and any actively bleeding vessels controlledwith suture ligation.176HepatoduodenalligamentCommonbile ductHepaticarteryPortal veinPringle maneuverMARROW4 P's in the management of liver injuries are:• Push compression of the edges of the laceration••-Pringle applying pressure on the portal triadPlug the defects with silicon tubes•-Pack apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleeding.Prolonged intraoperative use of Pringle maneuver can lead to hepatic ischemia and necrosis.

questions.explanation: The given clinical history and X-ray image showing obliteration of the diaphragmatic outline aresuggestive of traumatic diaphragmatic injury in this patient. Penetrating diaphragmatic injurymust be repaired via the abdomen and not the thorax, to rule out penetrating hollow viscusinjury.Patients with diaphragmatic injury are generally asymptomatic. Chest X ray after the insertion ofa nasogastric tube may help in identifying the herniation of the stomach in the thoracic cavity.However, the most accurate evaluation is by video assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) or laparoscopy.Abdominal contents may get herniated into the chest and get strangulated later. This is associatedwith high mortality. Hence, operative repair is indicated in all patients. The defect is closed withrunning 1-0 polypropylene suture.

questions.question: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being involved in a high-speed motorcyclecollision. He is hypotensive with a systolic pressure of 60 mm Hg. A FAST scan is positive. Atlaparotomy, he is found to have a large amount of bleeding from behind the liver withhollow-viscous perforation. Temporary application of a Pringle manoeuvre does not controlthe bleeding. However, laparotomy packs are placed, and the bleeding appears to slow down.The systolic blood pressure fails to increase even after aggressive resuscitation. The patient'spH is 7.06 and his temperature is 34°C. What would be the next best step in the managementof this patient?
questions.explanation: This patient has a blunt trauma abdomen. He is hypothermic and he is battling acidosis. Thus, heshould be subjected to damage control surgery and must be shifted to ICU for furtherresuscitation.177Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definitesurgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressiveresuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.3 Phases:Phase I (Initial Exploration) -This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of activehemorrhage and contamination.Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia,coagulopathy, and acidosis.Phase III (Definitive Operation) -It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typicallyoccurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.Pringle's manoeuvre can be performed to decrease the active haemorrhage from the liver in a liverlaceration. It is done by applying pressure on the portal triad at the Foramen of Winslow. Thepressure can be applied either digitally or with the use of a soft clamp.Rapid control of the vessels entering the porta hepatis can be obtained by compressing them inthe free edge of the lesser omentum.Porta hepatis is a deep, transverse fissure that is situated on the inferior surface of the rightlobe of the liver.Structures entering at porta hepatis:• Portal vein•• Hepatic artery•Hepatic nervous plexusStructures exiting the porta hepatis:• Right and left hepatic bile ducts•• LymphaticsThe images attached below shows the porta hepatis and the gif demonstrates the pringlesmanoeuvre.178PortahepatisLymphaticsPorta hepatis.HepatoduodenalligamentCommonbile ductHepaticarteryPortal veinPorta hepatisOMARROWPringle maneuverMARROWOMARROWPortal veinHepatic arteryLobar nervesBile duct1794 P's in the management of liver injuries are:• Push- Compression of the edges of the laceration•Pringle- Applying pressure on the portal triad••Plug the defects with silicon tubes•Pack- Apply packs in and around the liver to arrest bleedingGeneral guidelines for the management of blunt trauma to the liver:• Patients who are haemodynamically unstable will require an immediate laparotomy for damagecontrol resuscitation.• For the patient who is haemodynamically stable, imaging by CT should be performed to furtherevaluate the nature of the injury.• Most patients with a blunt liver injury who are haemodynamically stable can be managedconservatively.•• The indication for discontinuing conservative treatment is the development of haemodynamicinstability, evidence of ongoing blood loss despite correction of any underlying coagulopathy andthe development of signs of generalised peritonitis.•Interventional radiology has an important role in the management of liver trauma andembolisation to control hepatic artery bleeding is safe and effective in a stable patient with noevidence of hollow viscus perforation.180
